PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of caution to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no two people answer it in exactly the same way. Others may not share some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank or unanswered.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they hold no interest for you.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada for 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer life
- Pioneer church
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan and in the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
Starr, David Henry
Indian Head, Sask., 1954

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

RULE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name ...............................................................
2. Your address ...............................................................
3. Date ...............................................................
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) ...............................................................
5. What was your father's name and occupation? ...............................................................
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? ...............................................................
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates and reasons stated by yourself. ...............................................................

3. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you do not know.) I was in my teens, etc.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

I had a brother and my father living over here.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Mail order or government information?)

I had someone who had survived this country. My daughter lives near the first merchant pioneer in Winnipeg.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

My mother and I.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By train and boat (Great Lakes).

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Qu'Appelle, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Qu'Appelle, Sask.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Just Qu'Appelle & Indian Head.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Worked farming when friend came out west for 12 years.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Bessie Clayton McMichael — in 1901 — In Apple.

21. Did anyone else come to Seabattown because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My brother & father came here

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Used to go to church (held in the school) by walking (about one mile) rain in fall & spring often stay one half hour.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   My brother had the second car in 1946.

26. If you owned a car before 1941, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   In Appelle - 4 or 5 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns)
   Yes, I went to another town.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Sometimes I would go twice a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also if you paid cash or credit.
   Of your total purchases why by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1902 - D.H. Strick (My own company)

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of starting permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   We decided to stay when we left the east.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My brother was County Commissioner of the Town & Rural Municipality of La Ronge April 1st, 1920 to March 31st, 1920.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district mention it here. Giving dates whenever possible.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any change in name since the first name was given; date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Named by my father.
6.

39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, letters, photographs, programs, minutes books of community organizations, reminiscences, etc.? (Attach any additional pages)

Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Assembly, Library, Region, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations:

Children:
- Mr. John Lawrence - Indian Head
- Mrs. Mary Lawrence - Indian Head

Grandchildren:
- Mr. William Lawrence - Indian Head
- Mrs. Mary Lawrence - Indian Head

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

(Mrs.) Eleanor Lawrence
Archives Division Office

Oxford.
